name: Check symptoms and follow up
title: ANC.DT.03 Check symptoms and follow up
description: Depending on current and/or persistant symptoms, physiological symptoms counselling may be required

action.title: ANC.DT.03 Check symptoms and follow up

trigger.name: ANC.B7 Check symptoms and follow up

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on non-pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting
action.textEquivalent: Ginger, chamomile, vitamin B6 and/or acupuncture are recommended for the relief of nausea in early pregnancy, depending on a woman’s preferences and available options. Women should be informed that symptoms of nausea and vomiting usually resolve in the second half of pregnancy.

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.1. Nausea and vomiting (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting
action.textEquivalent: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting, such as doxylamine and metoclopramide, should be reserved for those pregnant women experiencing distressing symptoms that are not relieved by non-pharmacological options, under the supervision of a medical doctor

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.1. Nausea and vomiting (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on diet and lifestyle changes to prevent and relieve heartburn
action.textEquivalent: Advice on diet and lifestyle is recommended to prevent and relieve heartburn in pregnancy. Antacid preparations can be offered to women with troublesome symptoms that are not relieved by lifestyle modification.

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.2. Heartburn (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on antacid preparations to relieve heartburn
action.textEquivalent: Antacid preparations can be offered to women with troublesome symptoms that are not relieved by lifestyle modification. Magnesium carbonate and aluminium hydroxide preparations are probably unlikely to cause harm in recommended dosages.

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.2. Heartburn (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on non-pharmacological treatment for the relief of leg cramps
action.textEquivalent: Non-pharmacological therapies, including muscle stretching, relaxation, heat therapy, dorsiflexion of the foot, and massage can be used for the relief of leg cramps in pregnancy

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.3. Leg cramps (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on magnesium and calcium to relieve leg cramps
action.textEquivalent: If leg cramps are not relieved with non-pharmacological measures, then give 300–360 mg magnesium per day in two or three divided doses; give calcium 1 g twice daily for two weeks

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.3. Leg cramps (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.description: Counselling on regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain
action.textEquivalent: Regular exercise throughout pregnancy is recommended to prevent low back and pelvic pain. There are a number of different treatment options that can be used, such as physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture, depending and based on a woman’s preferences and available options.

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.4. Low back and pelvic pain (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

expression.description:
("Current physiological symptoms" = "Low back pain")
  AND (Current physiological symptoms" ≠ "Contractions" OR "Pain during urination (dysuria)" OR "Extreme pelvic pain, can"t walk (symphysis pubis dysfunction)")

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
Counselling on regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain
Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms
action.description: Coinselling on regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain conducted
action.textEquivalent: Regular exercise throughout pregnancy is recommended to prevent low back and pelvic pain. There are a number of different treatment options that can be used, such as physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture, depending and based on a woman’s preferences and available options.

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.4. Low back and pelvic pain (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

expression.description:
("Current physiological symptoms" = "Pelvic pain")
  AND (Current physiological symptoms" ≠ "Contractions" OR "Pain during urination (dysuria)" OR "Extreme pelvic pain, cannot walk (symphysis pubis dysfunction)")

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms
action.description: Counselling on regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain
action.textEquivalent: Regular exercise throughout pregnancy is recommended to prevent low back and pelvic pain. There are a number of different treatment options that can be used, such as physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture, depending and based on a woman’s preferences and available options.

expression.description:
("Persistent physiological symptoms" = "Low back pain")
  AND (Current physiological symptoms" ≠ "Contractions" OR "Pain during urination (dysuria)" OR "Extreme pelvic pain, cannot walk (symphysis pubis dysfunction)")

action.description: Counselling on regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain
action.textEquivalent: Regular exercise throughout pregnancy is recommended to prevent low back and pelvic pain. expression.description:
("Persistent physiological symptoms" = "Pelvic pain")
  AND (Current physiological symptoms" ≠ "Contractions" OR "Pain during urination (dysuria)" OR "Extreme pelvic pain, cannot walk (symphysis pubis dysfunction)")

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on dietary modifications to relieve constipation
action.textEquivalent: Dietary modifications to relieve constipation include promoting adequate intake of water and dietary fibre (found in vegetables, nuts, fruits and whole grains)

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.5. Constipation (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on wheat bran or other fibre supplements to relieve constipation
action.textEquivalent: Wheat bran or other fibre supplements can be used to relieve constipation, if dietary modifications are not enough, and if they are available and appropriate

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.5. Constipation (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

action.title: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms (see Annotations for pop-up message)
action.description: Counselling on non-pharmacological options for varicose veins and oedema
action.textEquivalent: Non-pharmacological options, such as compression stockings, leg elevation and water immersion, can be used for the management of varicose veins and oedema in pregnancy, depending and based on a woman’s preferences and available options

documentation.label:
WHO ANC recommendations (2016): D.6. Varicose veins and oedema (3)
WHO consolidated self-care interventions guidelines (2019) (4)

expression.description:
("Current physiological symptoms" = "Varicose veins")
  AND (Current physiological symptoms" ≠ "Leg pain" OR "Leg redness")

action.textEquivalent: Non-pharmacological options, such as compression stockings, leg elevation and water immersion, can be used for the management of varicose veins and oedema in pregnancy, depending and based on a woman’s preferences and available options

action.description: Investigate any possible complications or onset of labour
action.textEquivalent: Please investigate any possible complications or onset of labour, related to low back and pelvic pain

action.textEquivalent: Woman has dysuria – please investigate urinary tract infection and treat if positive
